I am shocked that it took until the 37th commenter to note that a similarly egregious experiment took place on US soil against US citizens of African descent. (See the Tuskegee Experiment) We don't need to look to Nazis for examples of sadistically inhumane policy; our own history provides enough heinous examples. These parallel stories have common themes of white supremacy, the arrogant abuse of the powerful preying upon the powerless, science unconstrained by ethics, and the tragi-comically delayed apology lacking any substantive redress to the victims, their families, or their communities. The more things change...

The problem, which if you do any research about that time era-beginning of time to about 1960- human rights were a joke, in general.  because there were no laws or standards to be held to, "IN the name of science" was used rampantly to disguise, "IN HINDSIGHT", what truly were atrocities.  No race, creed or class is exempt from hate, discrimination, or jealousy. To hold people modern laws and social norms ex pos facto is not really how anyone should act.  However, we should work some sort of assistance or aid/charity package out for them (being family and "participants" in the study).  A thing to remember is it takes a seriously intelligent and amazing person to break a status quo, if you take a minute and think, everyone that does breaks the status quo, we study as very important historical figures.

Apologizing to the president of Guatemala is odd. He's one in a string of US-supported governments who has made life hell for the indigenous people since we overthrew their government in 1954.  Even if he's not of the really bad ones, he's a member of the European-descended elite who lives in a world apart from the people who were (and are) abused.  We should be apologizing to the people of that time, some of whom are still living; and to their descendants. Many of these descendants are the "illegal alien invaders" who struggled to come to the U.S. to escape the mess we made there, whom our politicians now bash in order to build their careers and whom our teenagers beat and kill for sport.

I  was at the NIH in 1966-68. Everybody knew about the Tuskegee study but were afraid [we were draftees serving in lieu of Viet Nam.] to say anything. Some called us the  Yellow Berets. To have done this study in the light of Tuskegee is more than 'unethical'.

Apology? AND NO MENTION OF COMPENSATION!!!! This a national shame, an humiliation. Our President ought to be on the net plane with a check.
What kind of a nation were we, are we, do we wish ourselves to be.

There was a discussion just the other day of secrets. This is the exact reason there ought to be none, that all ought to be in the open.

Almost a million of your grandparents and ancestors either died or got terribly maimed in the first half of the 20th century to wipe this sort of lunacy from off of the face of the earth, and their memory has now been badly marred. Please accept my condolences for that matter.
Maybe you should hunt those people down, and have them test-driving your state of the art electric chairs. Perhaps you should hunt them down, ship them to Guatemala, and deliver them to the relatives of those who have perished in these experiments. Or even, first the later, and then the former, in case any of those sickos survive at all. But, please, do hunt them down. They are still breathing.
By the tone of the commentaries I read, I feel that you are with us from abroad on this one: that we all must claim that something very very serious must be done to those criminals, in order to prove that the history of those who died throughout the world, from everywhere, in the name of a so-called free world, cannot be regarded as a vain wasteful one.
America, you have got to dig yourself out of the hole you’re in, and in no time. Late: it already is.
We, the people from the free world which still is, need you for what you have once stood for before us all.

Not this!
